title: If you think the ability to feel grief is the sole preserve of the hum
text:
If you think the ability to feel grief is the sole preserve of the human race, think again. In an incredible BBC video posted last week, a group of langurs in Rajasthan can be seen mourning the ‘death’ of a robot monkey planted in their midst to observe them.
It all begins when one of the langurs drops the robot – which resembles a baby monkey — from its perch on a tree. The troop of langurs believe that the ‘baby’ has died, and they take turns to come and see the corpse.
Incredibly, they hug and comfort each other, just like we do at funerals – or when we learn of a particularly tragic incident.
It all goes to show that monkeys, which are among our closest genetic cousins in the animal kingdom, may be more similar to us than we think.
